title: Boy died after doctor missed disease that he could have survived with treatment
text:
Ryan Morse, 12, died in December 2012 from Addison’s disease (Picture: Wales News Service)

A doctor faces being sacked after dismissing a 12-year-old boy’s deadly disease as a common virus, which went on to kill him just hours later.

Dr Joanne Rudling, 49, failed to spot that Ryan Morse was suffering from Addison’s disease, a rare condition that causes the adrenal glands in the kidneys stop functioning.

Ryan’s weight dramatically dropped to just four stone and his genitals turned black before he died on his settee at the family home.

Devastated mum Carol Morse, 57, said her concerns for his welfare were repeatedly waved away by medics.

An inquest previously heard Dr Rudling said Ryan’s darkening skin was down to puberty – a claim she denied.

The inquest in Newport, South Wales, heard Ryan’s death ‘could have been prevented’.

Dr Rudling, who worked at Abernant Surgery in Abertillery, South Wales, is facing misconduct allegations.

Dr Joanne Rudling, 49, failed to spot Ryan’s rare condition (Picture: Wales News Service)

She is due to appear before a Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service panel in Manchester next month.

The allegation is that, between November and December 2012, she ‘failed to provide adequate clinical care’ to Ryan.

She is also accused of ‘dishonestly’ making a retrospective entry in Ryan’s medical records on December 10, 2012.

Ryan dropped to just four stone and his genitals turned black before he died on his settee at the family home (Picture: Wales News Service)

The tribunal will also look at whether the doctor dishonestly provided Gwent Police with ‘untrue information.’

Dr Rudling, of Cardiff, and colleague Dr Lindsey Thomas were previously charged with manslaughter by gross negligence.

But they were cleared at Cardiff Crown Court and Dr Rudling was later acquitted of attempting to pervert the course of justice.

The tribunal will take place between November 4 and 22.

What is Addison's disease? Addison’s disease is a rare disorder affecting the adrenal glands which sit on top of the kidneys The glands produce two key hormones: cortisol and aldosterone The damage to the adrenal gland as a result of Addison’s disease, means it does not produce enough cortisol or aldosterone Symptoms include: Lack of energy or motivation

Increased thirst

Loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss

Low mood

Muscle weakness
description: Ryan Morse, 12, was suffering from Addison’s disease, a rare condition that causes the adrenal glands in the kidneys stop functioning.
